elements.content: Reactive oxygen species (ROS)-based cancer treatments have attracted much attention in recent years. However, most patients respond poorly to the monotypic ROS during these treatments. In this work, a multiple ROS-based cancer immunotherapy synergistic strategy has been developed to enhance the therapeutic effect of cancer. We prepare a three-dimensional covalent organic framework (3D COF-TATB), and embed copper ions (Cu2+) into the skeleton to obtain multifunctional nanomaterial, 3D Cu@COF-TATB. In this system, porphyrins in 3D COF-TATB serve not only as the photosensitizer for photodynamic process to produce singlet oxygen­(1O2), but also as the binding sites to complex with Cu2+. Cu2+ can be reduced by the GSH to generate Cu+ to produce hydroxyl radical (•OH) through the Fenton-like reaction. Moreover, the generated multiple types of ROS induce the immunogenic cell death (ICD) of cancer cells to improve the immunogenicity and further activate an immune response for attacking the tumor. Combining with the immunoblocking inhibitor (aPD-1), 3D Cu@COF-TATB can effectively inhibit the tumor growth. This work will provide a guidance for multimodal cancer therapy in future clinical treatment settings.
elements.clean_text: Reactive oxygen species (ROS)-based cancer treatments have attracted much attention in recent years. However, most patients respond poorly to the monotypic ROS during these treatments. In this work, a multiple ROS-based cancer immunotherapy synergistic strategy has been developed to enhance the therapeutic effect of cancer. We prepare a three-dimensional covalent organic framework (3D COF-TATB), and embed copper ions (Cu2+) into the skeleton to obtain multifunctional nanomaterial, 3D Cu@COF-TATB. In this system, porphyrins in 3D COF-TATB serve not only as the photosensitizer for photodynamic process to produce singlet oxygen(1O2), but also as the binding sites to complex with Cu2+. Cu2+ can be reduced by the GSH to generate Cu+ to produce hydroxyl radical (⋅OH) through the Fenton-like reaction. Moreover, the generated multiple types of ROS induce the immunogenic cell death (ICD) of cancer cells to improve the immunogenicity and further activate an immune response for attacking the tumor. Combining with the immunoblocking inhibitor (aPD-1), 3D Cu@COF-TATB can effectively inhibit the tumor growth. This work will provide a guidance for multimodal cancer therapy in future clinical treatment settings.

elements.content: ROS are highly active substances with oxygen free radicals produced in the process of oxidative stress, which play an important regulatory role in cell communication and diseases. Studies have shown that the increased ROS can induce cell apoptosis through many internal and external pathways. Therefore, many therapeutic drugs have been applied to stimulate cells for producing high levels of ROS to damage cancer cells. Among the ROS-based therapeutic strategies, photodynamic therapy (PDT) is an effective method, which has promoted the treatment of bladder, prostate, and kidney cancer in clinic. However, the application of PDT is often limited due to the depth of light penetration. Chemodynamic therapy (CDT) uses metal ions to directly catalyze hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) or oxygen (O2) to produce ROS without light sources, and its wider application has greatly promoted ROS-based cancer treatment. The cancer treatments are often less effective due to the short life span and limited spread distance of ROS when ROS is used to kill cancer cells. With the development of cancer therapy, it has been found that the elevated ROS can cause cells to suffer a death mode that express immunogen, also known as ICD. Cells that undergo ICD can express damage associated molecular pattern molecules (DAMPs), such as calreticulin (CRT), adenosine triphosphate (ATP), heat shock protein (HSP), high mobility group protein B1 (HMGB1) signaling molecules, etc. to enhance immunogenicity. Then the dendritic cells (DC) and cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTL) are recruited to the tumor tissue to initiate and perpetuate the immune response against cancer. Therefore, it is desirable to develop nanoplatforms to produce multiple ROS for improving the therapeutic effect of immunotherapy.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

ROS are highly active substances with oxygen free radicals produced in the process of oxidative stress, which play an important regulatory role in cell communication and diseases. Studies have shown that the increased ROS can induce cell apoptosis through many internal and external pathways. Therefore, many therapeutic drugs have been applied to stimulate cells for producing high levels of ROS to damage cancer cells. Among the ROS-based therapeutic strategies, photodynamic therapy (PDT) is an effective method, which has promoted the treatment of bladder, prostate, and kidney cancer in clinic. However, the application of PDT is often limited due to the depth of light penetration. Chemodynamic therapy (CDT) uses metal ions to directly catalyze hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) or oxygen (O2) to produce ROS without light sources, and its wider application has greatly promoted ROS-based cancer treatment. The cancer treatments are often less effective due to the short life span and limited spread distance of ROS when ROS is used to kill cancer cells. With the development of cancer therapy, it has been found that the elevated ROS can cause cells to suffer a death mode that express immunogen, also known as ICD. Cells that undergo ICD can express damage associated molecular pattern molecules (DAMPs), such as calreticulin (CRT), adenosine triphosphate (ATP), heat shock protein (HSP), high mobility group protein B1 (HMGB1) signaling molecules, etc. to enhance immunogenicity. Then the dendritic cells (DC) and cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTL) are recruited to the tumor tissue to initiate and perpetuate the immune response against cancer. Therefore, it is desirable to develop nanoplatforms to produce multiple ROS for improving the therapeutic effect of immunotherapy.

elements.content: Covalent organic framework (COF) is an emerging class of novel crystalline materials with ordered porous structures formed by thermodynamically controlled polymerization, which is made from light elements, typically C, H, O, N, or B through reversible covalent bonds. COF has exhibited tremendous potential as nanodrug candidates for cancer therapy due to their excellent property including large surface area, regular pores, changeable structural composition, etc. COF is positionally controlled in two dimensions (2D) or three dimensions (3D) according to their different geometry of building blocks. 3D COF is extended networks of molecular building blocks organized in all three dimensions, which has numerous open sites and active sites to show promising applications in various fields, especially gas storage, catalysis, drug delivery, and cancer therapy. In addition, 3D COF with porphyrin molecules can produce ROS under the laser irradiation, which has been considered as excellent candidate for the ROS-based therapy.

COF has exhibited tremendous potential as nanodrug candidates for cancer therapy due to their excellent property including large surface area, regular pores, changeable structural composition, etc. COF is positionally controlled in two dimensions (2D) or three dimensions (3D) according to their different geometry of building blocks. 3D COF is extended networks of molecular building blocks organized in all three dimensions, which has numerous open sites and active sites to show promising applications in various fields, especially gas storage, catalysis, drug delivery, and cancer therapy. In addition, 3D COF with porphyrin molecules can produce ROS under the laser irradiation, which has been considered as excellent candidate for the ROS-based therapy.

elements.content: Herein, we developed a multiple ROS-based cancer immunotherapy strategy for fighting against cancer efficiently. A novel porphyrin-containing 3D COF (3D COF-TATB) was synthesized as the main part of nanodrugs. Porphyrins in the 3D COF-TATB served not only as the photosensitizer to generate 1O2 for PDT, but also as the binding sites to complex with Cu2+. More interestingly, the as-synthesized 3D Cu@COF-TATB can catalyze H2O2 into •OH through Fenton-like reaction, which effectively improved the synergistic therapy effect by producing different types of ROS (). The generated ROS further induce the ICD of cancer cells to improve the immunogenicity and further stimulate the body’s antitumor immune response. Moreover, the exposed CRT and released HMGB1 promote the maturation of DCs and the delivery of antigens to T cells. Combining with the immunoblocking inhibitor (aPD-1), this strategy can effectively inhibit the tumor growth and provide guidance for multimodal cancer therapy.

More interestingly, the as-synthesized 3D Cu@COF-TATB can catalyze H2O2 into ⋅OH through Fenton-like reaction, which effectively improved the synergistic therapy effect by producing different types of ROS (). The generated ROS further induce the ICD of cancer cells to improve the immunogenicity and further stimulate the body's antitumor immune response. Moreover, the exposed CRT and released HMGB1 promote the maturation of DCs and the delivery of antigens to T cells. Combining with the immunoblocking inhibitor (aPD-1), this strategy can effectively inhibit the tumor growth and provide guidance for multimodal cancer therapy.

elements.content: An ampule bottle measuring 10 × 8 mm (o.d. × i.d.) was charged with TAPA (13 mg, 0.026 mmol), TBAP (22.8 mg, 0.031 mmol), 1.0 mL of 1,2-dichlorobenzene, and 0.2 mL of 6 M aqueous acetic acid solution. The bottle was flash frozen at 77 K (liquid N2 bath), evacuated to an internal pressure of below 8 Pa and flame-sealed. The reaction was heated at 140 °C for 5 days, yielding a yellow solid, which was isolated by filtration and washed with anhydrous N,N-dimethylacetamide and anhydrous tetrahydrofuran (THF), the resulting powder was immersed in anhydrous THF for 24 h and dried at room temperature and under vacuum at 100 °C overnight.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of 3D COF-TATB

An ampule bottle measuring 10 × 8 mm (o.d. × i.d.) was charged with TAPA (13 mg, 0.026 mmol), TBAP (22.8 mg, 0.031 mmol), 1.0 mL of 1,2-dichlorobenzene, and 0.2 mL of 6 M aqueous acetic acid solution. The bottle was flash frozen at 77 K (liquid N2 bath), evacuated to an internal pressure of below 8 Pa and flame-sealed. The reaction was heated at 140 °C for 5 days, yielding a yellow solid, which was isolated by filtration and washed with anhydrous N,N-dimethylacetamide and anhydrous tetrahydrofuran (THF), the resulting powder was immersed in anhydrous THF for 24 h and dried at room temperature and under vacuum at 100 °C overnight.

elements.content: The mixture of 3D COF-TATB (1 mg) and CuCl2•2H2O (1.34 mg) were ground by the agate mortar and pulverized by sonic probe for 2 h (1500 W) to obtain the nanoscale 3D COF-TATB. Then the mixed solution was stirred for 24 h and sonicated for 6 h (360 W) to fully complex Cu2+. The obtained 3D Cu@COF-TATB were collected via centrifugation and washed with water for three times to remove the unreacted CuCl2 (12 000 rpm, 10 min).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 3D Cu@COF-TATB

The mixture of 3D COF-TATB (1 mg) and CuCl2⋅2H2O (1.34 mg) were ground by the agate mortar and pulverized by sonic probe for 2 h (1500 W) to obtain the nanoscale 3D COF-TATB. Then the mixed solution was stirred for 24 h and sonicated for 6 h (360 W) to fully complex Cu2+. The obtained 3D Cu@COF-TATB were collected via centrifugation and washed with water for three times to remove the unreacted CuCl2 (12000 rpm, 10 min).

elements.content: MB was employed to determine the generated •OH. For MB degradation assay, MB was added into the 3D COF-TATB and 3D Cu@COF-TATB solutions (0.25 mg/mL) with or without H2O2. After incubated for 60 min, the solutions were centrifugated and the UV–vis absorbance spectra of the supernatants were detected.
elements.clean_text:
Detection of ⋅OH with MB

MB was employed to determine the generated ⋅OH. For MB degradation assay, MB was added into the 3D COF-TATB and 3D Cu@COF-TATB solutions (0.25 mg/mL) with or without H2O2. After incubated for 60 min, the solutions were centrifugated and the UV-vis absorbance spectra of the supernatants were detected.

elements.content: To investigate the production of ROS by 3D Cu@COF-TATB, DCFH was added into 3D Cu@COF-TATB (0.1 mg/mL) solution, and the solutions were irradiated with 635 nm laser, the fluorescence properties of the solutions with different treatments were recorded (Ex = 488 nm, Em = 520 nm).
elements.clean_text:
Detection of ROS with DCFH

To investigate the production of ROS by 3D Cu@COF-TATB, DCFH was added into 3D Cu@COF-TATB (0.1 mg/mL) solution, and the solutions were irradiated with 635 nm laser, the fluorescence properties of the solutions with different treatments were recorded (Ex = 488 nm, Em = 520 nm).

elements.content: 4T1 cells were dispersed in 96-well droplets at 37 °C for 24 h. After that, the cells were incubated with different concentrations of 3D COF-TATB and 3D Cu@COF-TATB for 6 h. Then the cells were irradiated with 635 nm laser (0.637 W/cm2) for 10 min and incubated overnight. 150 μL of MTT solution (0.5 mg/mL) was further added to each well for another 4 h. After removing the remaining MTT medium, 150 μL of DMSO was added to each well to dissolve the formazan crystal. The absorbance was measured at 490 nm with microplate reader.
elements.clean_text:
MTT Assay

4T1  cells were dispersed in 96-well droplets at 37 °C for 24 h. After that, the cells were incubated with different concentrations of 3D COF-TATB and 3D Cu@COF-TATB for 6 h. Then the cells were irradiated with 635 nm laser (0.637 W/cm2) for 10 min and incubated overnight. 150 μL of MTT solution (0.5 mg/mL) was further added to each well for another 4 h. After removing the remaining MTT medium, 150 μL of DMSO was added to each well to dissolve the formazan crystal. The absorbance was measured at 490 nm with microplate reader.

elements.content: 4T1 cells were divided into 6 groups and treated with (1), PBS; (2), PBS + Laser; (3), 3D COF-TATB; (4), 3D Cu@COF-TATB; (5), 3D COF-TATB + Laser; (6), 3D Cu@COF-TATB + Laser. After 4 h, the cells were incubated with 1 mL of 1640 containing 1 μL of DCFH-DA for 20 min and then irradiated with 635 nm laser for 10 min. Subsequently, the cells were washed with PBS solution and further analyzed with confocal laser scanning microscopy (CLSM) (Ex = 488 nm, Em = 510–580 nm).

elements.content: The expression of CRT was detected by immunofluorescence staining. Cells were divided into six groups and treated with (1), PBS; (2), PBS + Laser; (3), 3D COF-TATB; (4), 3D Cu@COF-TATB; (5), 3D COF-TATB + laser; (6), 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser for 4 h. elements.content: The expression of HMGB1 in cell nucleus was detected by immunofluorescence staining. Cells were divided into 6 groups and treated with (1), PBS; (2), PBS + Laser; (3), 3D COF-TATB; (4), 3D Cu@COF-TATB; (5), 3D COF-TATB + laser; (6), 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser for 4 h. After that, the cells were irradiated with 635 nm laser for 10 min and were further cultured overnight. All cells were fixed with paraformaldehyde for 10 min and permeated with Triton X-100 for 5 min. Then cells were incubated with primary antibodies (anti-HMGB1) at room temperature for 1 h. Then cells were stained with the second antibody at room temperature for 1 h and stained with Hoechst 33342 for 10 min. After washed with PBS, the cells were studied by the CLSM.

elements.content: First, 5 × 105 4T1 cells were subcutaneously administered to the right flank of the Balb/C mice as primary tumors. After 3 days, 5 × 105 4T1 cells were subcutaneously administered to the left flank of the Balb/C mice as distal tumors. The calculation formula of tumor volume: V = (tumor width)2 × (tumor length)/2. The tumor-bearing mice were divided into seven groups: (1), PBS; (2), PBS + laser; (3), 3D COF-TATB; (4), 3D Cu@COF-TATB; (5), 3D COF-TATB + laser; (6), 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser; (7), 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser + aPD-1. Different materials (5 mg/kg) were injected into the primary tumor sites of mice. Then, mice were irradiated by 635 nm laser for 10 min. The 200 μg of aPD-1 was injected intravenously on days 1, 3, and 5. Body weights, volumes of primary and distal tumors were recorded every 2 days. After 14 days, the primary tumors and main organs were collected for H&E staining.

In Vivo Therapeutic Effect

First, 5 × 105 4T1 cells were subcutaneously administered to the right flank of the Balb/C mice as primary tumors. After 3 days, 5 × 105 4T1 cells were subcutaneously administered to the left flank of the Balb/C mice as distal tumors. The calculation formula of tumor volume: V = (tumor width)2 × (tumor length)/2. The tumor-bearing mice were divided into seven groups: (1), PBS; (2), PBS + laser; (3), 3D COF-TATB; (4), 3D Cu@COF-TATB; (5), 3D COF-TATB + laser; (6), 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser; (7), 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser + aPD-1. Different materials (5 mg/kg) were injected into the primary tumor sites of mice. Then, mice were irradiated by 635 nm laser for 10 min. The 200 μg of aPD-1 was injected intravenously on days 1, 3, and 5. Body weights, volumes of primary and distal tumors were recorded every 2 days. After 14 days, the primary tumors and main organs were collected for H&E staining.

elements.content: The 3D porphyrin-based COF-TATB was first prepared by a classical solvothermal method (Supporting Information (SI) Figure S1). The as-prepared 3D COF-TATB was then ground and crushed in mortar to obtain uniform COF particles in nanometer scale. The crystal structures of 3D COF-TATB was proved via the PXRD analysis. As shown in SI Figure S2, a strong peak at 6.67° and an acromion at 7.20° were observed. The 3D COF-TATB was further modified with Cu2+ through the coordination between the porphyrin ring and Cu2+ to obtain 3D Cu@COF-TATB. From the FT-IR spectrum (A), the characteristic peak of 3D COF-TATB at 1610 cm–1 indicated the formation of C = N linkage. And the characteristic peak of N–H bond in the porphyrin ring of 3D Cu@COF-TATB was moved from 964 to 999 cm–1, which confirmed the successful coordination of Cu2+. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (B) and Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (SI Figure S3) images showed that 3D COF-TATB and 3D Cu@COF-TATB had uniform morphology and size. Moreover, the hydrodynamic sizes of 3D COF-TATB and 3D Cu@COF-TATB were about 100 nm by dynamic light scattering (DLS) (C). The stability of 3D Cu@COF-TATB was further studied. In SI Figure S4, the hydrodynamic size of 3D Cu@COF-TATB was basically unchanged for 7 days, indicating the long-term stability of 3D Cu@COF-TATB.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Preparation and Characterizations of 3D Cu@COF-TATB

The 3D porphyrin-based COF-TATB was first prepared by a classical solvothermal method (Supporting Information (SI) Figure S1). The as-prepared 3D COF-TATB was then ground and crushed in mortar to obtain uniform COF particles in nanometer scale. The crystal structures of 3D COF-TATB was proved via the PXRD analysis. As shown in SI Figure S2, a strong peak at 6.67° and an acromion at 7.20° were observed. The 3D COF-TATB was further modified with Cu2+ through the coordination between the porphyrin ring and Cu2+ to obtain 3D Cu@COF-TATB. From the FT-IR spectrum (A), the characteristic peak of 3D COF-TATB at 1610 cm-1 indicated the formation of C = N linkage. And the characteristic peak of N-H bond in the porphyrin ring of 3D Cu@COF-TATB was moved from 964 to 999 cm-1, which confirmed the successful coordination of Cu2+. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (B) and Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (SI Figure S3) images showed that 3D COF-TATB and 3D Cu@COF-TATB had uniform morphology and size. Moreover, the hydrodynamic sizes of 3D COF-TATB and 3D Cu@COF-TATB were about 100 nm by dynamic light scattering (DLS) (C). The stability of 3D Cu@COF-TATB was further studied. In SI Figure S4, the hydrodynamic size of 3D Cu@COF-TATB was basically unchanged for 7 days, indicating the long-term stability of 3D Cu@COF-TATB.

elements.content: In this system, the Cu2+ is reduced by the GSH to generate the Cu+ and GSSH. Then Cu+ reacts with H2O2 to produce •OH and Cu2+ through a Fenton-like reaction. Hence, the GSH consumption level was investigated first. As shown in SI Figure S5, the GSH level obviously decreased in the GSH+3D Cu@COF-TATB group, while negligible changed in GSH+3D COF-TATB group, which indicated that the Cu2+ reacted with GSH to exert CDT. Then the catalytic properties and doping efficiency of Cu2+ were further assessed. In order to study the catalytic performance of 3D COF-TATB and 3D Cu@COF-TATB, the methylene blue (MB) degradation experiments were carried out. The Cu catalytic site in 3D Cu@COF-TATB has the ability to catalyze the conversion of H2O2 to •OH through the Fenton-like reaction. As shown in D,E, the blue MB was degraded to colorless and the absorption intensity of MB at 664 nm significantly decreased with the addition of 3D Cu@COF-TATB and H2O2. The result verified that 3D Cu@COF-TATB could be used as a potential nanozyme for CDT via Fenton-like reaction. Interestingly, we found that this 3D COF-TATB also had a certain catalytic performance of H2O2 to •OH, which is the main reason that the 3D COF-TATB was chosen in this work. The absorption intensity of MB in 3D COF-TATB with H2O2 reduced by nearly 4 times compared to that without H2O2 (E), which indicated the catalytic property of 3D COF-TATB to generate ROS without laser irradiation. Subsequently, the ability of 3D Cu@COF-TATB to generate 1O2 was studied utilizing 9,10-anthracenediyl-bis­(methylene)­dimalonic acid (ABMD) and 2,7-dichlorofluorescein (DCFH). As shown in F,G, only laser irradiated produced almost no singlet oxygen and other ROS, which indicated that no influence was caused by the laser irradiation. As shown in F, the absorbance intensity of ABMD treated with 3D Cu@COF-TATB obviously decreased after laser irradiation, which suggested that 3D Cu@COF-TATB had good ability to produce 1O2 under 635 nm light irradiation. And the experimental results by DCFH probe were consistent with the above results (G), which also verify the ROS production capacity of 3D Cu@COF-TATB. In a word, 3D Cu@COF-TATB could produce a variety of highly toxic ROS to fight against cancer. Studies have shown that paramagnetic metal ions can inhibit the photosensitization of porphyrin, thus affecting the effect of PDT. Therefore, we further investigated the optimal Cu2+ binding efficiency of 3D COF-TATB via DCFH probe. The total amount of produced ROS was adjusted by changing the ratio of 3D COF-TATB and Cu2+. As can be seen in the H,I, with the increase of Cu2+, the generation of ROS first rose and then fell. When the mass ratio of Cu2+ to 3D COF-TATB was 1:2, the ROS produced by 3D Cu@COF-TATB was the most significant, which was about 10 times more than that of 3D COF-TATB alone. However, as the ratio of Cu2+ to 3D COF-TATB exceeded 1:2, the 3D Cu@COF-TATB, the total production of ROS by 3D Cu@COF-TATB gradually decreased because the coordination of Cu2+ limited the ability of porphyrins to generate 1O2. Under optimal condition (Cu2+: 3D COF-TATB = 1:2), the coordination efficiency of Cu2+ in 3D COF-TATB was about 0.039 mg mg–1 measured by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS) (Figure S6).
elements.clean_text: In this system, the Cu2+ is reduced by the GSH to generate the Cu+ and GSSH. Then Cu+ reacts with H2O2 to produce ⋅OH and Cu2+ through a Fenton-like reaction. Hence, the GSH consumption level was investigated first. As shown in SI Figure S5, the GSH level obviously decreased in the GSH+3D Cu@COF-TATB group, while negligible changed in GSH+3D COF-TATB group, which indicated that the Cu2+ reacted with GSH to exert CDT. Then the catalytic properties and doping efficiency of Cu2+ were further assessed. In order to study the catalytic performance of 3D COF-TATB and 3D Cu@COF-TATB, the methylene blue (MB) degradation experiments were carried out. The Cu catalytic site in 3D Cu@COF-TATB has the ability to catalyze the conversion of H2O2 to ⋅OH through the Fenton-like reaction. As shown in D,E, the blue MB was degraded to colorless and the absorption intensity of MB at 664 nm significantly decreased with the addition of 3D Cu@COF-TATB and H2O2. The result verified that 3D Cu@COF-TATB could be used as a potential nanozyme for CDT via Fenton-like reaction. Interestingly, we found that this 3D COF-TATB also had a certain catalytic performance of H2O2 to ⋅OH, which is the main reason that the 3D COF-TATB was chosen in this work. The absorption intensity of MB in 3D COF-TATB with H2O2 reduced by nearly 4 times compared to that without H2O2 (E), which indicated the catalytic property of 3D COF-TATB to generate ROS without laser irradiation. Subsequently, the ability of 3D Cu@COF-TATB to generate 1O2 was studied utilizing 9,10-anthracenediyl-bis(methylene)dimalonic acid (ABMD) and 2,7-dichlorofluorescein (DCFH). As shown in F,G, only laser irradiated produced almost no singlet oxygen and other ROS, which indicated that no influence was caused by the laser irradiation. As shown in F, the absorbance intensity of ABMD treated with 3D Cu@COF-TATB obviously decreased after laser irradiation, which suggested that 3D Cu@COF-TATB had good ability to produce 1O2 under 635 nm light irradiation. And the experimental results by DCFH probe were consistent with the above results (G), which also verify the ROS production capacity of 3D Cu@COF-TATB. In a word, 3D Cu@COF-TATB could produce a variety of highly toxic ROS to fight against cancer. Studies have shown that paramagnetic metal ions can inhibit the photosensitization of porphyrin, thus affecting the effect of PDT. Therefore, we further investigated the optimal Cu2+ binding efficiency of 3D COF-TATB via DCFH probe. The total amount of produced ROS was adjusted by changing the ratio of 3D COF-TATB and Cu2+. As can be seen in the H,I, with the increase of Cu2+, the generation of ROS first rose and then fell. When the mass ratio of Cu2+ to 3D COF-TATB was 1:2, the ROS produced by 3D Cu@COF-TATB was the most significant, which was about 10 times more than that of 3D COF-TATB alone. However, as the ratio of Cu2+ to 3D COF-TATB exceeded 1:2, the 3D Cu@COF-TATB, the total production of ROS by 3D Cu@COF-TATB gradually decreased because the coordination of Cu2+ limited the ability of porphyrins to generate 1O2. Under optimal condition (Cu2+: 3D COF-TATB = 1:2), the coordination efficiency of Cu2+ in 3D COF-TATB was about 0.039 mg mg-1 measured by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS) (Figure S6).

elements.content: We further studied the intracellular therapeutic effect of the 3D COF-TATB and 3D Cu@COF-TATB by MTT assays. The survival rate of 4T1 cells was up to more than 90% under laser irradiation alone, which indicated that the power and irradiation time that we chose had low cytotoxicity. In the absence of laser irradiation, 4T1 cells had a lower survival rate after incubated with 3D Cu@COF-TATB than that of 3D COF-TATB, indicating the good CDT effect of 3D Cu@COF-TATB. And cells treated with 3D COF-TATB or 3D Cu@COF-TATB showed significant concentration-dependent toxicity under laser irradiation (A). In addition, the cell killing efficiency of 3D COF-TATB and 3D Cu@COF-TATB was verified by the live/dead cell staining assay. As shown in B, cancer cells pretreated with 3D Cu@COF-TATB and laser irradiation exhibited strongest red fluorescence and weakest green fluorescence among all the groups, implying that the 3D Cu@COF-TATB under laser irradiation had the most severe lethality to living cells. Subsequently, 2,7-dichlorofluorescein diacetate (DCFH-DA) was used to study the ability of 3D COF-TATB and 3D Cu@COF-TATB to produce ROS in vitro. As illustrated in C,D, 4T1 cells incubated with 3D Cu@COF-TATB under laser irradiation showed the most intensely green fluorescence, suggesting the excellent ROS production performance in cancer cells. In addition, compared with 3D COF-TATB, the cells treated with 3D Cu@COF-TATB exhibited stronger green fluorescence signal, which indicated that Cu2+ could be reduced to Cu+ by GSH and further catalyze the transformation of H2O2 into •OH to generate more ROS in cells. These results were further demonstrated via flow cytometry assay. 4T1 cells treated with 3D Cu@COF-TATB and laser irradiation showed the strongest fluorescent signal in E, which also suggested its ability to produce ROS. Excess ROS can trigger mitochondrial destruction to induce cell apoptosis. The mitochondrial membrane potential (MMP) of 4T1 cells with different treatments were studied by rhodamine 123. As shown in SI Figure S7, the MMP decreased with the increase of ROS. In particular, the MMP decreased the most obviously in the group of 3D Cu@COF-TATB under laser irradiation, which verified that the serious mitochondrial destruction was caused by excess ROS.

elements.content: ROS triggered by PDT and CDT caused the ICD of cancer cells, which induced strong anticancer immunity. CRT and HMGB1 are two important biomarkers of ICD. CRT migrates from the endoplasmic reticulum to the cell surface to stimulate DCs. HMGB1 is released from the nucleus to recruit DCs to the dying cancer cells. To further test the ICD of cancer cells, 4T1 cells were incubated with 3D COF-TATB or 3D Cu@COF-TATB for 6 h with or without laser irradiation to study CRT exposure and HMGB1 release by immunostaining analysis. A,B showed that CRT expression of 4T1 cells obviously increased after treated with 3D COF-TATB or 3D Cu@COF-TATB under laser irradiation, implying that the ICD of cancer cells were induced. Notably, the most CRT expression was observed after treated with 3D Cu@COF-TATB under laser irradiation among the six groups, indicating that 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser irradiation induced the most potent ICD of 4T1 cells (A,B). HMGB1 was initially distributed in the nucleus and would be released to the extracellular after various treatments (C,D). Cells treated with 3D Cu@COF-TATB and laser irradiation showed the weakest red fluorescence in the nucleus, indicating that most HMGB1 was released outside the cells. In the absence of laser irradiation, the red fluorescence significantly decreased in 3D Cu@COF-TATB compared with 3D COF-TATB and PBS, which was consistent with the ICD result of CRT immunofluorescence staining (A,B). The above results suggested that this strategy could induce a potent ICD to elicit antitumor immune responses.

ROS-Induced ICD Response

ROS triggered by PDT and CDT caused the ICD of cancer cells, which induced strong anticancer immunity. CRT and HMGB1 are two important biomarkers of ICD. CRT migrates from the endoplasmic reticulum to the cell surface to stimulate DCs. HMGB1 is released from the nucleus to recruit DCs to the dying cancer cells. To further test the ICD of cancer cells, 4T1 cells were incubated with 3D COF-TATB or 3D Cu@COF-TATB for 6 h with or without laser irradiation to study CRT exposure and HMGB1 release by immunostaining analysis. A,B showed that CRT expression of 4T1 cells obviously increased after treated with 3D COF-TATB or 3D Cu@COF-TATB under laser irradiation, implying that the ICD of cancer cells were induced. Notably, the most CRT expression was observed after treated with 3D Cu@COF-TATB under laser irradiation among the six groups, indicating that 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser irradiation induced the most potent ICD of 4T1 cells (A,B). HMGB1 was initially distributed in the nucleus and would be released to the extracellular after various treatments (C,D). Cells treated with 3D Cu@COF-TATB and laser irradiation showed the weakest red fluorescence in the nucleus, indicating that most HMGB1 was released outside the cells. In the absence of laser irradiation, the red fluorescence significantly decreased in 3D Cu@COF-TATB compared with 3D COF-TATB and PBS, which was consistent with the ICD result of CRT immunofluorescence staining (A,B). The above results suggested that this strategy could induce a potent ICD to elicit antitumor immune responses.

elements.content: In order to evaluate the in vivo antitumor therapeutic effects of proximal and distal tumors, a 4T1 bilateral subcutaneous tumor-bearing model was established. In this model, mice were first inoculated with 4T1 cells on the one side and then inoculated on the other side 3 days later (A). Inhibiting of PD-1/PD-L1 signaling pathway is a common method of clinical immune checkpoint blocking therapy in recent years. Therefore, we used the antibody of PD-1 (aPD-1) to interrupt PD-1/PD-L1 signaling pathway in combination with 3D Cu@COF-TATB to enhance antitumor immunity in vivo. The tumor-bearing mice were randomly assigned into seven groups and intratumorally injected with (1) PBS; (2) PBS + laser; (3) 3D COF-TATB; (4) 3D Cu@COF-TATB; (5) 3D COF-TATB + laser; (6) 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser; (7) 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser + aPD-1, respectively. As illustrated in B and SI Figure S8A, the tumor inhibition effect of PBS, PBS + laser and 3D COF-TATB group was negligible, which indicated that laser alone and 3D COF-TATB had poor therapy efficacy against tumor. And the inhibition effect of 3D Cu@COF-TATB was moderate because 3D Cu@COF-TATB only produced •OH by CDT. After laser irradiation, the growth of tumors was suppressed in 3D COF-TATB + laser group through PDT to some extent. And 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser group showed obvious tumor inhibition due to the production of multiple ROS through PDT and CDT, indicating that the multiple ROS-based strategy had better antitumor effect. H&E staining analysis was also observed that 3D Cu@COF-TATB under laser radiation induced extensive tumor cells apoptosis (D), which was consistent with the above results. We further studied the abscopal antitumor effect of 3D COF-TATB and 3D Cu@COF-TATB. The distant tumors grew rapidly in PBS, PBS + laser and 3D COF-TATB group. In the 3D Cu@COF-TATB, 3D COF-TATB + laser, 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser and 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser + aPD-1 groups, the distal tumors showed varying degrees of inhibition. And 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser + aPD-1 had the best inhibitory effect on distal tumors, suggesting that 3D Cu@COF-TATB combining with aPD-1 caused systemic immune responses to inhibit the growth of abscopal tumor (C and SI Figure S8B). CD3+ and CD8+ T cells in tumors were studied by the immunofluorescence staining assay to proof the immune response. After treatments, the tumors of mice were gained and stained. SI Figure S9 showed that 3D Cu@COF-TATB+laser + aPD-1 group exhibited the most CD3+ and CD8+ T cells in tumor slides, which indicated the most significant immune response. Additionally, body weights (E) of mice remained negligible changed during treatments, which showed the biocompatibility of the materials. H&E staining images of major organs (heart, liver, spleen, lung, and kidney) indicated that no obvious damage was caused to normal tissues (SI Figure S10). These experiments indicated the good biological safety and tumor inhibition effect of 3D Cu@COF-TATB, which will advance the application potential in vivo.

In Vivo Antitumor Therapeutic Effect

In order to evaluate the in vivo antitumor therapeutic effects of proximal and distal tumors, a 4T1 bilateral subcutaneous tumor-bearing model was established. In this model, mice were first inoculated with 4T1 cells on the one side and then inoculated on the other side 3 days later (A). Inhibiting of PD-1/PD-L1 signaling pathway is a common method of clinical immune checkpoint blocking therapy in recent years. Therefore, we used the antibody of PD-1 (aPD-1) to interrupt PD-1/PD-L1 signaling pathway in combination with 3D Cu@COF-TATB to enhance antitumor immunity in vivo. The tumor-bearing mice were randomly assigned into seven groups and intratumorally injected with (1) PBS; (2) PBS + laser; (3) 3D COF-TATB; (4) 3D Cu@COF-TATB; (5) 3D COF-TATB + laser; (6) 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser; (7) 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser + aPD-1, respectively. As illustrated in B and SI Figure S8A, the tumor inhibition effect of PBS, PBS + laser and 3D COF-TATB group was negligible, which indicated that laser alone and 3D COF-TATB had poor therapy efficacy against tumor. And the inhibition effect of 3D Cu@COF-TATB was moderate because 3D Cu@COF-TATB only produced ⋅OH by CDT. After laser irradiation, the growth of tumors was suppressed in 3D COF-TATB + laser group through PDT to some extent. And 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser group showed obvious tumor inhibition due to the production of multiple ROS through PDT and CDT, indicating that the multiple ROS-based strategy had better antitumor effect. H&E staining analysis was also observed that 3D Cu@COF-TATB under laser radiation induced extensive tumor cells apoptosis (D), which was consistent with the above results. We further studied the abscopal antitumor effect of 3D COF-TATB and 3D Cu@COF-TATB. The distant tumors grew rapidly in PBS, PBS + laser and 3D COF-TATB group. In the 3D Cu@COF-TATB, 3D COF-TATB + laser, 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser and 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser + aPD-1 groups, the distal tumors showed varying degrees of inhibition. And 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser + aPD-1 had the best inhibitory effect on distal tumors, suggesting that 3D Cu@COF-TATB combining with aPD-1 caused systemic immune responses to inhibit the growth of abscopal tumor (C and SI Figure S8B). CD3+ and CD8+ T cells in tumors were studied by the immunofluorescence staining assay to proof the immune response. After treatments, the tumors of mice were gained and stained. SI Figure S9 showed that 3D Cu@COF-TATB+laser + aPD-1 group exhibited the most CD3+ and CD8+ T cells in tumor slides, which indicated the most significant immune response. Additionally, body weights (E) of mice remained negligible changed during treatments, which showed the biocompatibility of the materials. H&E staining images of major organs (heart, liver, spleen, lung, and kidney) indicated that no obvious damage was caused to normal tissues (SI Figure S10). These experiments indicated the good biological safety and tumor inhibition effect of 3D Cu@COF-TATB, which will advance the application potential in vivo.

elements.content: In summary, the 3D COF-TATB was constructed and embedded with Cu2+ to obtain 3D Cu@COF-TATB for the ROS-based cancer immunotherapy. The 3D COF-TATB served not only as the nanocarrier to bind with Cu2+ as a CDT agent, but also as the PDT agent in this strategy. Moreover, the 3D COF-TATB can catalyze H2O2 into the •OH to improve the efficiency of generating ROS. The 3D Cu@COF-TATB can produce various ROS (1O2 and •OH) under the exposure of laser at 635 nm to induce the ICD of cancer cells for enhanced antitumor immune response. Compared with the strategy that produces single ROS, 3D Cu@COF-TATB can improve the variety and efficiency of generated ROS. Experimental results verified that 3D Cu@COF-TATB possessed excellent capacity to strengthen the ICD of cancer cells and stimulate the immune response for fighting against cancer by assistance of aPD-1. We expect this combination therapy strategy to advance the development of ROS-based immunotherapy.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, the 3D COF-TATB was constructed and embedded with Cu2+ to obtain 3D Cu@COF-TATB for the ROS-based cancer immunotherapy. The 3D COF-TATB served not only as the nanocarrier to bind with Cu2+ as a CDT agent, but also as the PDT agent in this strategy. Moreover, the 3D COF-TATB can catalyze H2O2 into the ⋅OH to improve the efficiency of generating ROS. The 3D Cu@COF-TATB can produce various ROS (1O2 and ⋅OH) under the exposure of laser at 635 nm to induce the ICD of cancer cells for enhanced antitumor immune response. Compared with the strategy that produces single ROS, 3D Cu@COF-TATB can improve the variety and efficiency of generated ROS. Experimental results verified that 3D Cu@COF-TATB possessed excellent capacity to strengthen the ICD of cancer cells and stimulate the immune response for fighting against cancer by assistance of aPD-1. We expect this combination therapy strategy to advance the development of ROS-based immunotherapy.

cln_elements.content:
An ampule bottle measuring 10 × 8 mm (o.d. × i.d.) was charged with TAPA (13 mg, 0.026 mmol), TBAP (22.8 mg, 0.031 mmol), 1.0 mL of 1,2-dichlorobenzene, and 0.2 mL of 6 M aqueous acetic acid solution. The bottle was flash frozen at 77 K (liquid N2 bath), evacuated to an internal pressure of below 8 Pa and flame-sealed. The reaction was heated at 140 °C for 5 days, yielding a yellow solid, which was isolated by filtration and washed with anhydrous N,N-dimethylacetamide and anhydrous tetrahydrofuran (THF), the resulting powder was immersed in anhydrous THF for 24 h and dried at room temperature and under vacuum at 100 °C overnight.

Synthesis of 3D Cu@COF-TATB

The mixture of 3D COF-TATB (1 mg) and CuCl2•2H2O (1.34 mg) were ground by the agate mortar and pulverized by sonic probe for 2 h (1500 W) to obtain the nanoscale 3D COF-TATB. Then the mixed solution was stirred for 24 h and sonicated for 6 h (360 W) to fully complex Cu2+. The obtained 3D Cu@COF-TATB were collected via centrifugation and washed with water for three times to remove the unreacted CuCl2 (12 000 rpm, 10 min).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of 3D COF-TATB

An ampule bottle measuring 10 × 8 mm (o.d. × i.d.) was charged with TAPA (13 mg, 0.026 mmol), TBAP (22.8 mg, 0.031 mmol), 1.0 mL of 1,2-dichlorobenzene, and 0.2 mL of 6 M aqueous acetic acid solution. The bottle was flash frozen at 77 K (liquid N2 bath), evacuated to an internal pressure of below 8 Pa and flame-sealed. The reaction was heated at 140 °C for 5 days, yielding a yellow solid, which was isolated by filtration and washed with anhydrous N,N-dimethylacetamide and anhydrous tetrahydrofuran (THF), the resulting powder was immersed in anhydrous THF for 24 h and dried at room temperature and under vacuum at 100 °C overnight.

Synthesis of 3D Cu@COF-TATB

The mixture of 3D COF-TATB (1 mg) and CuCl2⋅2H2O (1.34 mg) were ground by the agate mortar and pulverized by sonic probe for 2 h (1500 W) to obtain the nanoscale 3D COF-TATB. Then the mixed solution was stirred for 24 h and sonicated for 6 h (360 W) to fully complex Cu2+. The obtained 3D Cu@COF-TATB were collected via centrifugation and washed with water for three times to remove the unreacted CuCl2 (12000 rpm, 10 min).

cln_elements.content:
The 3D porphyrin-based COF-TATB was first prepared by a classical solvothermal method (Supporting Information (SI) Figure S1). The as-prepared 3D COF-TATB was then ground and crushed in mortar to obtain uniform COF particles in nanometer scale. The crystal structures of 3D COF-TATB was proved via the PXRD analysis. As shown in SI Figure S2, a strong peak at 6.67° and an acromion at 7.20° were observed. The 3D COF-TATB was further modified with Cu2+ through the coordination between the porphyrin ring and Cu2+ to obtain 3D Cu@COF-TATB. From the FT-IR spectrum (A), the characteristic peak of 3D COF-TATB at 1610 cm–1 indicated the formation of C = N linkage. And the characteristic peak of N–H bond in the porphyrin ring of 3D Cu@COF-TATB was moved from 964 to 999 cm–1, which confirmed the successful coordination of Cu2+. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (B) and Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (SI Figure S3) images showed that 3D COF-TATB and 3D Cu@COF-TATB had uniform morphology and size. Moreover, the hydrodynamic sizes of 3D COF-TATB and 3D Cu@COF-TATB were about 100 nm by dynamic light scattering (DLS) (C). The stability of 3D Cu@COF-TATB was further studied. In SI Figure S4, the hydrodynamic size of 3D Cu@COF-TATB was basically unchanged for 7 days, indicating the long-term stability of 3D Cu@COF-TATB.

In this system, the Cu2+ is reduced by the GSH to generate the Cu+ and GSSH. Then Cu+ reacts with H2O2 to produce •OH and Cu2+ through a Fenton-like reaction. Hence, the GSH consumption level was investigated first. As shown in SI Figure S5, the GSH level obviously decreased in the GSH+3D Cu@COF-TATB group, while negligible changed in GSH+3D COF-TATB group, which indicated that the Cu2+ reacted with GSH to exert CDT. Then the catalytic properties and doping efficiency of Cu2+ were further assessed. In order to study the catalytic performance of 3D COF-TATB and 3D Cu@COF-TATB, the methylene blue (MB) degradation experiments were carried out. The Cu catalytic site in 3D Cu@COF-TATB has the ability to catalyze the conversion of H2O2 to •OH through the Fenton-like reaction. As shown in D,E, the blue MB was degraded to colorless and the absorption intensity of MB at 664 nm significantly decreased with the addition of 3D Cu@COF-TATB and H2O2. The result verified that 3D Cu@COF-TATB could be used as a potential nanozyme for CDT via Fenton-like reaction. Interestingly, we found that this 3D COF-TATB also had a certain catalytic performance of H2O2 to •OH, which is the main reason that the 3D COF-TATB was chosen in this work. The absorption intensity of MB in 3D COF-TATB with H2O2 reduced by nearly 4 times compared to that without H2O2 (E), which indicated the catalytic property of 3D COF-TATB to generate ROS without laser irradiation. Subsequently, the ability of 3D Cu@COF-TATB to generate 1O2 was studied utilizing 9,10-anthracenediyl-bis­(methylene)­dimalonic acid (ABMD) and 2,7-dichlorofluorescein (DCFH). As shown in F,G, only laser irradiated produced almost no singlet oxygen and other ROS, which indicated that no influence was caused by the laser irradiation. As shown in F, the absorbance intensity of ABMD treated with 3D Cu@COF-TATB obviously decreased after laser irradiation, which suggested that 3D Cu@COF-TATB had good ability to produce 1O2 under 635 nm light irradiation. And the experimental results by DCFH probe were consistent with the above results (G), which also verify the ROS production capacity of 3D Cu@COF-TATB. In a word, 3D Cu@COF-TATB could produce a variety of highly toxic ROS to fight against cancer. Studies have shown that paramagnetic metal ions can inhibit the photosensitization of porphyrin, thus affecting the effect of PDT. Therefore, we further investigated the optimal Cu2+ binding efficiency of 3D COF-TATB via DCFH probe. The total amount of produced ROS was adjusted by changing the ratio of 3D COF-TATB and Cu2+. As can be seen in the H,I, with the increase of Cu2+, the generation of ROS first rose and then fell. When the mass ratio of Cu2+ to 3D COF-TATB was 1:2, the ROS produced by 3D Cu@COF-TATB was the most significant, which was about 10 times more than that of 3D COF-TATB alone. However, as the ratio of Cu2+ to 3D COF-TATB exceeded 1:2, the 3D Cu@COF-TATB, the total production of ROS by 3D Cu@COF-TATB gradually decreased because the coordination of Cu2+ limited the ability of porphyrins to generate 1O2. Under optimal condition (Cu2+: 3D COF-TATB = 1:2), the coordination efficiency of Cu2+ in 3D COF-TATB was about 0.039 mg mg–1 measured by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS) (Figure S6).

The Intracellular Antitumor Performance of 3D Cu@COF-TATB

We further studied the intracellular therapeutic effect of the 3D COF-TATB and 3D Cu@COF-TATB by MTT assays. The survival rate of 4T1 cells was up to more than 90% under laser irradiation alone, which indicated that the power and irradiation time that we chose had low cytotoxicity. In the absence of laser irradiation, 4T1 cells had a lower survival rate after incubated with 3D Cu@COF-TATB than that of 3D COF-TATB, indicating the good CDT effect of 3D Cu@COF-TATB. And cells treated with 3D COF-TATB or 3D Cu@COF-TATB showed significant concentration-dependent toxicity under laser irradiation (A). In addition, the cell killing efficiency of 3D COF-TATB and 3D Cu@COF-TATB was verified by the live/dead cell staining assay. As shown in B, cancer cells pretreated with 3D Cu@COF-TATB and laser irradiation exhibited strongest red fluorescence and weakest green fluorescence among all the groups, implying that the 3D Cu@COF-TATB under laser irradiation had the most severe lethality to living cells. Subsequently, 2,7-dichlorofluorescein diacetate (DCFH-DA) was used to study the ability of 3D COF-TATB and 3D Cu@COF-TATB to produce ROS in vitro. As illustrated in C,D, 4T1 cells incubated with 3D Cu@COF-TATB under laser irradiation showed the most intensely green fluorescence, suggesting the excellent ROS production performance in cancer cells. In addition, compared with 3D COF-TATB, the cells treated with 3D Cu@COF-TATB exhibited stronger green fluorescence signal, which indicated that Cu2+ could be reduced to Cu+ by GSH and further catalyze the transformation of H2O2 into •OH to generate more ROS in cells. These results were further demonstrated via flow cytometry assay. 4T1 cells treated with 3D Cu@COF-TATB and laser irradiation showed the strongest fluorescent signal in E, which also suggested its ability to produce ROS. Excess ROS can trigger mitochondrial destruction to induce cell apoptosis. The mitochondrial membrane potential (MMP) of 4T1 cells with different treatments were studied by rhodamine 123. As shown in SI Figure S7, the MMP decreased with the increase of ROS. In particular, the MMP decreased the most obviously in the group of 3D Cu@COF-TATB under laser irradiation, which verified that the serious mitochondrial destruction was caused by excess ROS.

In Vivo Antitumor Therapeutic Effect

In order to evaluate the in vivo antitumor therapeutic effects of proximal and distal tumors, a 4T1 bilateral subcutaneous tumor-bearing model was established. In this model, mice were first inoculated with 4T1 cells on the one side and then inoculated on the other side 3 days later (A). Inhibiting of PD-1/PD-L1 signaling pathway is a common method of clinical immune checkpoint blocking therapy in recent years. Therefore, we used the antibody of PD-1 (aPD-1) to interrupt PD-1/PD-L1 signaling pathway in combination with 3D Cu@COF-TATB to enhance antitumor immunity in vivo. The tumor-bearing mice were randomly assigned into seven groups and intratumorally injected with (1) PBS; (2) PBS + laser; (3) 3D COF-TATB; (4) 3D Cu@COF-TATB; (5) 3D COF-TATB + laser; (6) 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser; (7) 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser + aPD-1, respectively. As illustrated in B and SI Figure S8A, the tumor inhibition effect of PBS, PBS + laser and 3D COF-TATB group was negligible, which indicated that laser alone and 3D COF-TATB had poor therapy efficacy against tumor. And the inhibition effect of 3D Cu@COF-TATB was moderate because 3D Cu@COF-TATB only produced •OH by CDT. After laser irradiation, the growth of tumors was suppressed in 3D COF-TATB + laser group through PDT to some extent. And 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser group showed obvious tumor inhibition due to the production of multiple ROS through PDT and CDT, indicating that the multiple ROS-based strategy had better antitumor effect. H&E staining analysis was also observed that 3D Cu@COF-TATB under laser radiation induced extensive tumor cells apoptosis (D), which was consistent with the above results. We further studied the abscopal antitumor effect of 3D COF-TATB and 3D Cu@COF-TATB. The distant tumors grew rapidly in PBS, PBS + laser and 3D COF-TATB group. In the 3D Cu@COF-TATB, 3D COF-TATB + laser, 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser and 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser + aPD-1 groups, the distal tumors showed varying degrees of inhibition. And 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser + aPD-1 had the best inhibitory effect on distal tumors, suggesting that 3D Cu@COF-TATB combining with aPD-1 caused systemic immune responses to inhibit the growth of abscopal tumor (C and SI Figure S8B). CD3+ and CD8+ T cells in tumors were studied by the immunofluorescence staining assay to proof the immune response. After treatments, the tumors of mice were gained and stained. SI Figure S9 showed that 3D Cu@COF-TATB+laser + aPD-1 group exhibited the most CD3+ and CD8+ T cells in tumor slides, which indicated the most significant immune response. Additionally, body weights (E) of mice remained negligible changed during treatments, which showed the biocompatibility of the materials. H&E staining images of major organs (heart, liver, spleen, lung, and kidney) indicated that no obvious damage was caused to normal tissues (SI Figure S10). These experiments indicated the good biological safety and tumor inhibition effect of 3D Cu@COF-TATB, which will advance the application potential in vivo.

Results and Discussion

Preparation and Characterizations of 3D Cu@COF-TATB

Cu2+ Embedded Three-Dimensional Covalent
Organic Framework for Multiple ROS-Based Cancer Immunotherapy
